author: sky.cactus
content: What matters for the protocol is that validators generally agree on the time.  The most obvious schelling point for this is to use the current time as defined by society at large, which basically means NTP at the moment.

author: ryanleeschneider
content:
does the engine API "sync to head" process follow a fundamentally different flow when the EL/CL DBs are more than a couple hours behind head?  If for example I stop the CL and EL for say a day and then start them both up?  I'm seeing an issue w/ geth (1.13.2 in PBSS) and teku (23.9.1) not being able to fully sync to head but it only seems to happen if the two nodes are on a chain that's more than 12h or so old, or at least that's the pattern I'm seeing at the moment.  Annoyingly everything seems to work on a restart (e.g. to add more logging).

The reason this comes up is that we usually start new nodes by seeding them w/ a snapshot taken from a synced to head node that is backed up a couple times a day, but since I'm still experimenting w/ PBSS the snapshot is older than usual (say 20h behind head instead of 8 or so).  I'll collect logs once I get a better idea of what's going on, but in the meantime wanted to understand if there's a fundamental difference in control flow under this scenario.
